metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Ethics for children : a guide for teachers and parents, a \ published in 1910 by Cabot, Ella Lyman, an US \.
main_question:
Army stations were six weeks' journey apart, and in the wildest part of the country the soldiers did not dare go out without guards of a hundred men. Gordon started for Khartoum in April, riding sometimes forty-five miles a day on his camels, giving orders, writing letters, and holding interviews at the stations he passed through. He knew his work would be arduous, [masked clause revising an implied expectation]. "With terrific exertions," he wrote, "I may in two or three years with God's administration make a good province and suppress slave raids, and then I will come home and go to bed, never get up till noon every day and never walk more than a mile."

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause revising an implied expectation]:
source_title: Ethics for children : a guide for teachers and parents
answer_strings: but he was dauntless
but often these recruits would turn to the " captain," as they called him, listen to his replies, and then swear allegiance, as it were, to him
but he gave away to the pobr $2800
however much he prepared
passage: Army stations were six weeks' journey apart, and in the wildest part of the country the soldiers did not dare go out without guards of a hundred men. Gordon started for Khartoum in April, riding sometimes forty-five miles a day on his camels, giving orders, writing letters, and holding interviews at the stations he passed through. He knew his work would be arduous, but he was dauntless. "With terrific exertions," he wrote, "I may in two or three years with God's administration make a good province and suppress slave raids, and then I will come home and go to bed, never get up till noon every day and never walk more than a mile."

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Ethics for children : a guide for teachers and parents, a \ published in 1910 by Cabot, Ella Lyman, an US \.
main_question:
A LESSON FOR KINGS ¹ Once upon a time the future Buddha was born in India. He was a prince, and called Brahma-datta. As a boy, he was very good and learned; and when his father died, he became king of Benares. [masked sentence describing an inference or effect] The great Hall of Justice was closed because there were no disputes to settle.

Write a sentence appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked sentence describing an inference or effect]:
source_title: Ethics for children : a guide for teachers and parents
answer_strings: So just and righteous was he that none who had false cases dared appear before him; and, as the people knew that all injustice would be punished, they lived in peace and love.
So unjust and unrighteous was he that many with false cases appeared before him; and, as the people knew that all injustice would go unpunished, they lived in fear and hatred.
Therefore, he besought his councilors to tell him if they found any fault in him, but they one and all had only words of praise.
Hence the kingdom prospered under his fair and wise rule.
passage: A LESSON FOR KINGS ¹ Once upon a time the future Buddha was born in India. He was a prince, and called Brahma-datta. As a boy, he was very good and learned; and when his father died, he became king of Benares. So just and righteous was he that none who had false cases dared appear before him; and, as the people knew that all injustice would be punished, they lived in peace and love. The great Hall of Justice was closed because there were no disputes to settle.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Ethics for children : a guide for teachers and parents, a \ published in 1910 by Cabot, Ella Lyman, an US \.
main_question:
And when it was time to read her will, the people found that with all her giving, she had still saved a great deal of money, and that she had left every cent of it to the different orphan asylums of the city, each one of them was given something. Whether they were for white children or black, for Jews, Catholics, or Protestants, made no difference; [masked continuation] And just think, dears, that splendid, wise will was signed with a cross instead of a name, for Margaret had never learned to read or write!

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing a cause or reason]:
source_title: Ethics for children : a guide for teachers and parents
answer_strings: for Margaret always said, "They are all orphans alike."
for Jews, Catholics, or Protestants, made a significant difference
since each child deserved to be cared for equally
since she feared that racial prejudice would limit opportunities for some children, she ensured equal care
passage: And when it was time to read her will, the people found that with all her giving, she had still saved a great deal of money, and that she had left every cent of it to the different orphan asylums of the city, each one of them was given something. Whether they were for white children or black, for Jews, Catholics, or Protestants, made no difference; [masked continuation] And just think, dears, that splendid, wise will was signed with a cross instead of a name, for Margaret had never learned to read or write!

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Ethics for children : a guide for teachers and parents, a \ published in 1910 by Cabot, Ella Lyman, an US \.
main_question:
Hunger, cold, sickness, wounds, captivity, hard work, hard blows, all these were their portion and ours. Look at the records of other wars and you'll nowhere find examples of more courage in marching and fighting, or greater losses in camp and battle, than each side showed. [masked sentence describing a cause or reason] We wore them out.

Write a sentence appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked sentence describing a cause or reason]:
source_title: Ethics for children : a guide for teachers and parents
answer_strings: We won because we had more substitutes and more supplies; and also from the force of a larger patriotism on our side.
We lost because we had fewer substitutes and fewer supplies; and also from the lack of a larger patriotism on our side.
The sad become gay because of it.
Because the relentless hardships eroded their resolve, the soldiers’ spirits were exhausted, leaving them physically and mentally worn in the long campaign.
passage: Hunger, cold, sickness, wounds, captivity, hard work, hard blows, all these were their portion and ours. Look at the records of other wars and you'll nowhere find examples of more courage in marching and fighting, or greater losses in camp and battle, than each side showed. We won because we had more substitutes and more supplies; and also from the force of a larger patriotism on our side. We wore them out.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Ethics for children : a guide for teachers and parents, a \ published in 1910 by Cabot, Ella Lyman, an US \.
main_question:
He led a brave life. His sister Mary had times when she lost her reason, and at one of these times she actually killed her own mother, Lamb at once took Mary under his special protection for the rest of his life. He worked hard for thirty-three years at his counting-house in the city to earn money for her sake, [masked clause acknowledging a countervailing fact]. Mary was ill many times during her life, and Charles was always ready to help her through her hard times.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause acknowledging a countervailing fact]:
source_title: Ethics for children : a guide for teachers and parents
answer_strings: although he wanted above all things to be an author
though all men feared his iron will and respected his strong purpose, no one loved him
though he himself had financial struggles
though his health suffered greatly during those years, he persevered
passage: He led a brave life. His sister Mary had times when she lost her reason, and at one of these times she actually killed her own mother, Lamb at once took Mary under his special protection for the rest of his life. He worked hard for thirty-three years at his counting-house in the city to earn money for her sake, although he wanted above all things to be an author. Mary was ill many times during her life, and Charles was always ready to help her through her hard times.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Ethics for children : a guide for teachers and parents, a \ published in 1910 by Cabot, Ella Lyman, an US \.
main_question:
Not one of you would be here and would receive all that is given to you, unless many other men and women had worked hard for you. Do not too readily think that you have done enough simply because you have accomplished something. There is no enough, [masked clause describing an inference or effect]. Your success in life depends not on talents, but on will.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing an inference or effect]:
source_title: Ethics for children : a guide for teachers and parents
answer_strings: so long as you can better the lives of your fellow-beings
you should so continue to learn and improve
so you realize your achievements are merely the result of perseverance
passage: Not one of you would be here and would receive all that is given to you, unless many other men and women had worked hard for you. Do not too readily think that you have done enough simply because you have accomplished something. There is no enough, so long as you can better the lives of your fellow-beings. Your success in life depends not on talents, but on will.

main_question:
Scott drew out her picture, which he always carried with him, and tears came into his eyes at the thought that he might never see her again. "Well," said Lincoln at last, "you're not going to be shot. But tell me how can you repay me for setting you free and pardoning you?" Scott hesitated. "We're very poor," he said, "but I think we might get $500, [masked clause describing a condition or proviso] "No, that won't do," said Lincoln; "my bill is larger than that.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing a condition or proviso]:
source_title: Ethics for children : a guide for teachers and parents
answer_strings: if we mortgaged the farm."
if we didn't sell the farm
if God willed
insofar as we can raise it
provided that you help
passage: Scott drew out her picture, which he always carried with him, and tears came into his eyes at the thought that he might never see her again. "Well," said Lincoln at last, "you're not going to be shot. But tell me how can you repay me for setting you free and pardoning you?" Scott hesitated. "We're very poor," he said, "but I think we might get $500, if we mortgaged the farm." "No, that won't do," said Lincoln; "my bill is larger than that.
